data.title: Herbie, Come Home
data.meta_description: In 1969, Disney released the movie The Love Bug, featuring Herbie, a sentient 1963 Volkswagen Beetle with the racing style number “53” labeling his pearl-white body. In the film, race car driver Jim…
data.text:
Volkswagens, Beetles, and Herbie the Love Bug

My affliction with VW Beetle fever.

In 1969, Disney released the movie The Love Bug, featuring Herbie, a sentient 1963 Volkswagen Beetle with the racing style number “53” labeling his pearl-white body. In the film, race car driver Jim Douglas (played by Dean Jones) teams up with the VW Bug, which has a mind of its own. Douglas doesn’t realize the car’s value until a sneaky rival plots to steal him.

Fast forward to 1985.

After I separated from the United States Air Force, my wife and I moved to Scott Air Force Base in Illinois, where she would conclude her enlistment. I returned to college and started a new hobby, restoring a 1964 VW Beetle.

The old car had rusty fenders, holes in the floorboard, no back seat, a pushbutton in place of an ignition switch, and a hole in the dashboard, but its engine ran well. It had potential.

I devoured copies of Hot VWs and VW Trends magazines to learn how to restore and repair the machines. Most magazine photo spreads featured bikini-clad models showing off souped-up Beetles and Buses.
